Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Story: I stare at my phone, my partner’s message glowing on the screen: “Can’t wait for our weekend together. Just us.” It’s the last weekend before he leaves for months, and I promised we’d make every moment count. But my laptop pings again—Slack messages piling up, architects from three teams waiting for my input. The launch date was just moved up, and everyone’s blocked until I help define the new features. My manager’s email is clear: “We need your decisions ASAP.” I feel my chest tighten. I want to be present, to hold his hand and laugh over coffee, to make memories before he goes. But I also know the team is counting on me, and any delay could ripple through the project. My mind races, torn between the warmth of his smile and the cold urgency of deadlines. I can’t be in two places at once, but both need me now.
